The Affordable Care Act (ACA) enacted in 2010 has improved the lives of millions of Americans.  Six years later it has resulted in 1,781,000 Texans gaining health coverage and the uninsured rate in Texas has fallen by 28 percent. The Republicans plan to repeal the ACA will cause tens of millions of people to lose their health coverage and millions of Americans will be paying more for their insurance.    I will continue to work to ensure that the ACA stays in place, despite the uproar and support Republicans have put forth to dismantle it. I will push for Texas to expand Medicaid so that more Texans can receive the same benefits that millions of Americans in Medicaid expansion states currently receive. During the 115th Congress, I will make it my goal to improve the law so that we can fulfill the generations-long struggle to make health care a right, not a privilege, for all Americans. In honor of #BlackHistoryMonth we will honor those who have made contributions by uplifting and investing in the African American community.  Today we honor: Bessie Coleman. Born to sharecroppers in Atlanta, Texas, in 1892, Bessie Coleman was the first African-American woman pilot. Without any support from aviation schools in the U.S., Coleman sought training in France. After her return to the U.S., Coleman sought to give back to the community and champion for racial equality within aeronautics by conducting a series of lectures, flying exhibitions, and laying the grounds for an aviation school catered towards Black Americans before her death.  To learn more read here: https://airandspace.si.edu/files/pdf/explore-and-learn/teaching-posters/aviation.pdf

#Onthisday February 1,1960, four African American students sat at the lunch counter of Woolworth’s in Greensboro, North Carolina and were refused service by white waitresses. Despite six years passing since the landmark Brown vs. Board of Education Supreme Court decision, many states were still rooted in their traditions of racial exclusion. Starting with these four young freshmen, this sit-in influenced both black and white communities across the nation, with students in cities all over America staging their own peaceful protests. The dedication and courage of these students helped to encourage many stores and restaurants to integrate, with Woolworth’s itself notably desegregating in July of that same year. #BlackHistoryMonth

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor John Mason Brewer.   John Mason Brewer was a distinguished African-American folklorist during the early 1900s. Brewer utilized his craft for writing as he sought to portray and document Black history and culture. Through his projects including anthologies of poems and folklore from African-American poets and storytellers, Brewer managed to preserve the stories of black Texans while providing for a newly recognized source of the study of African-American culture. To learn more read here https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fbrbb

#Onthisday February 3, 1870 the 15th Amendment, granting African American men the right to vote was ratified. Despite ratification, discriminatory practices were still widely used to prevent African Americans from voting. The 15th Amendment set the precedent for the Voting Rights Act of 1965, which aimed to overcome the legal barriers that were often used to deny African Americans the right to vote despite the promise of the ratification of the 15th Amendment. #BlackHistoryMonth

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Debbie Allen.  Debbie Allen is an actress, dancer, director, and choreographer from Houston, Texas. As a result of her work on Broadway and in the television and film industry; Allen has received three Emmy awards, one Golden Globe award, and a NAACP Image award. As an activist, Allen utilizes her talents to create platforms for public discourse on social change through her projects in film, television, and theater, along with her own, Debbie Allen Dance Company. To learn more read here http://www.debbieallendanceacademy.com/about/debbie-allen

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Scott Joplin.  Scott Joplin was a pianist who contributed to the development of new styles of Black music in the late 1800s. As a result of his acquired fame from his performances throughout the United States, Joplin became known as a pioneer and developer of ragtime music. Through his composition of a developing genre, Joplin succeeded in creating and popularizing a distinctly indigenous African-American art form in American popular culture. To learn more read here https://www.britannica.com/biography/Scott-Joplin

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Henry O. Flipper.  Henry O. Flipper served as a 2nd Lieutenant in the U.S. Army, fighting among Buffalo Soldiers in the American Indian Wars throughout the late 1800s. As the first African American graduate of the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, Flipper acquired clout among his Army peers. Later he assumed the role as the first African American officer to lead the Buffalo Soldiers into battle in Texas and New Mexico. To learn more read here https://www.nps.gov/foda/learn/historyculture/secondlieutenanthenryflipper.htm

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Juanita J. Craft.  Juanita J. Craft was as a civil rights icon in the state of Texas. Having become a member of the NAACP, Craft helped organize 182 branches during her time as a Dallas membership chairman and Texas field organizer in the early 1940s. Moreover, Craft became the first African-American woman to vote in a public election in 1944 and fought for desegregation in public schools, colleges, and venues within the city of Dallas. Later in 1975, she would be elected to the Dallas City Council. To learn more read here: https://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/civilrights/tx1.htm

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Andrew “Rube” Foster.  Andrew “Rube” Foster was a celebrated baseball player and the founder of the Negro baseball league. Foster organized the Negro National League in 1920 due to its growing demand following the popularization of baseball. As a result of Foster’s contributions, at a time when many opportunities weren’t afforded to African-Americans, Foster and the Negro League allowed for the eventual destruction of the color barrier in Major League Baseball. To learn more read here: https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/ffo35

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Arthello Beck Jr. Dallas native, Arthello Beck Jr. was a self-taught artist who became the first African-American to own and operate an art gallery in the city of Dallas. With the intent of sharing and promoting African-American art, Beck displayed works of other African-American artists alongside his own in his Oak Cliff gallery. Beck’s work has been displayed in many venues including the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, the State Fair of Texas, and Dallas City Hall’s Great Court. To learn more read here: https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fbecf

#Onthisday we celebrate the 17th anniversary of Nelson Mandela’s release from prison. With his wife Winnie in hand, #Mandela was finally free to continue his mission after 27 years of imprisonment. That same day, with the whole world listening, Mandela advocated for the continuation of the growing movement against apartheid. He said, “To relax our efforts now would be a mistake, which generations to come will not be able to forgive.” Mandela, of course, followed through, and the apartheid soon ended.

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor John H. Yates. John H. Yates was born into slavery in Gloucester County, Virginia in 1828. Upon emancipation, Yates gained notoriety as a minister and missionary for the Freedmen community of Houston. Having founded the first Black Baptist church in Houston, Yates assisted in bringing the first Baptist college to Texas as a part of the church’s ministry, which prepared students for jobs in trade, business, and ministry. To learn more read here: https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fya07

#Onthisday we celebrate the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), which was founded on February 12, 1909. It has become America’s oldest and most recognized civil rights organization. It formed in response to the appalling practice of lynching, the 1908 Race Riot in Springfield, and a group of white liberals issued a call for a meeting to discuss racial justice. Approximately 60 people, including 7 African Americans signed the call, setting the precedent for the Association’s activism.

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Comer Cottrell.   Comer Cottrell was an entrepreneur who made the Jheri curl hair product accessible to the masses in 1980. With the popularization of the Curly Kit and the Kiddie Kit for children, Cottrell amassed millions of dollars which he used for leverage in his civic positions in the city of Dallas. Cottrell served as the first African-American in the Dallas Citizens’ Council and invested in the community by purchasing the campus of Bishop College only to move Paul Quinn College to the city to increase student enrollment. To learn more read here: http://www.npr.org/sections/codeswitch/2014/10/11/354931324/comer-cottrell-creator-of-the-peoples-jheri-curl-dies-at-82

#OnThisDay in 1920 during the convention of the National American Woman Suffrage Association, the League of Women voters was founded only six months before the 19th Amendment was ratified, giving women the right to vote. Beginning as a “mighty political experiment” the League was formed to help a new generation of women carry out their responsibilities as voters and shape public policy. As a nonpartisan organization, the League encourages members to be political, lobbying for social reform but neither supports or opposes candidates or political parties at any level of government.

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Samuel McCulloch Jr.  A free Black soldier of the Texas Revolution, Samuel McCulloch Jr. joined the Matagorda Volunteer Company in 1835 and later fought at Goliad where he was counted as the first Texan wounded in the Revolution. This namesake aided in his successful fight for the residential rights of free Blacks in Texas. As result of his work, all free Blacks residing in the state of Texas at the time of the Texas Declaration of Independence were granted permanent residency. To learn more read here: https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fmc36

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Bobby Seale. Bobby Seale is a political activist and co-founder of the Black Panther Party. Seale played an important role in galvanizing the movement towards Black empowerment in the late 1960s and early 1970s. Once promoting violence as a means to an end, Seale later reformed his views as he sought to enact change from within the political system when running for mayor of Oakland in 1973. Following his election loss, Seale has focused his efforts on improving social services in Black communities. To learn more read here: https://www.britannica.com/biography/Bobby-Seale

#Onthisday in 2005, the Kyoto Protocol became a binding agreement under which industrialized countries committed to reduce their greenhouse gases by 5.2% compared to their emissions in 1990. The protocol’s overall goal is to lower emissions from six greenhouse gases – carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, sulfur hexafluoride, HFC’s and PFC’s. The United States has committed to a 7% reduction in emissions.

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Antonio Maceo Smith. Antonio Maceo Smith was a civil rights activist within the city of Dallas. Smith was the executive secretary of the Dallas Negro Chamber of Commerce in 1933 and the deputy director of the Hall of Negro Life at the Texas Centennial Exposition in 1936. Smith championed for civil rights especially in his position in his local chapter of the NAACP and in the Dallas Independent School District. To learn more read here: http://www.dallasisd.org/domain/691

#Onthisday in 1929, The League of United Latin American Citizens (#LULAC) is one of the most widely recognized Hispanic civil rights organizations in the United States. Created to respond to the denial of civil rights experienced by Hispanic citizens, the League made dramatic progress during the 1930s working to desegregate hundreds of public places throughout Texas.  In 1945 the League notably and most successfully sued the Orange County School System, which had segregated its schools on the grounds that Mexican children were “more poorly clothed and mentally inferior to white children”.  Today, The League continues to fight for racial equality…they worked to support Sonia Sotomayor to be confirmed as the first Latina Supreme Court Justice.

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Pearl C. Anderson. Pearl C. Anderson was a public servant who moved to Dallas in hopes of gaining greater opportunity as a Black woman. After opening her own grocery store and accruing other properties, Anderson involved herself in the NAACP as a chair for the committee dedicated to investigating the bombings of Black-owned homes in the city. Anderson also contributed to the community while serving on the committee to bring Bishop College to Dallas and gave sizable donations to various organizations within the city of Dallas. To learn more read here: https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fan66

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor William J. Durham. William J. Durham was a civil rights activist and attorney was recognized as the most prominent Black lawyer in Texas by 1940. His notoriety and experience in civil rights cases were instrumental in his participation in the NAACP and in his assistance in fighting to desegregate The University of Texas Law School’s program in the Supreme Court case, Sweatt v. Painter (1950). To learn more read here: https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fdu46

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Wilhelmina Delco. Wilhelmina Delco served as a dedicated politician and educator in the Texas community. After being the first African-American elected to the Travis County School Board, Delco served 20 years in the Texas state legislature as an elected representative, chairing the House Higher Education Committee for 12 years until she was appointed speaker pro-tempore. This made her the first woman to assume the second highest position in the Texas House. To learn more read here: http://www.thehistorymakers.com/biography/honorable-wilhelmina-delco

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor James Farmer. James Farmer, a civil rights leader, played an instrumental role in the movement as he founded the Congress of Racial Equality (CORE). CORE was a proactive civil rights organization which frequently participated in sit-ins and other confrontational tactics in order to fight for desegregation of public places. Farmer’s dedication to civil rights is noted in his organization of the historic Freedom Rides of 1961. To learn more read here: https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/ffa19

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Lucretia Smiley Foster. Lucretia Smiley Foster was a journalist and civic leader in the city of Dallas. Foster also became the first African-American woman in Dallas to host a radio show in 1949. She found herself in the field of journalism as she wrote her own columns and eventually became heavily involved in the Dallas Post Tribune. To project a positive view of Black life and culture, Foster began the Dickie Foster Texas Black Women’s Conference and served on the board of Black museums such as the African-American Museum of Life and Culture. To learn more read here: https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/ffo69

#Onthisday in 1965 Malcolm X, an activist for poor and middle class Blacks in America, was assassinated while speaking at his rally in New York City.  After spending six years in prison for a burglary conviction, Malcolm X became a loyal and effective member of the Nation of Islam, where he advocated for self-defense and the liberation of African Americans.  His activism methods were in contrast to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s peaceful method, but he served as a necessary component for the civil rights movement.  Because of his departure from the Nation of Islam in 1963, it is believed that they were responsible for his assignation, but there’s still skepticism of who actually was in charge of his murder.

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Estevanico. Estevanico was an enslaved Moroccan who accompanied his master on the Spanish Panfilo de Narvaez expedition which was destined for Galveston, Texas. Upon arrival, Estevanico was titled the first African to explore Texas as a trusted aide to the Spanish colonialists in 1529. To learn more read here: https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fes08

#Onthisday in 1956, eighty nine African Americans, including Martin Luther King Jr. and Rosa Parks, voluntarily turned themselves in to authorities in Montgomery, Alabama. They had been indicted by a law from 1921, which prohibited conspiracies that interfered with lawful business; a statute designed to outlaw boycotting of businesses. Authorities charged Martin Luther King Jr. with organizing the black community to boycott buses in Montgomery, which had been planned by King to protest the towns for discriminatory segregation laws.

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Dallas Express. The Dallas Express was an African-American weekly newspaper in circulation from 1892 to 1970. The newspaper distinguished itself from others as it publicized incidents concerning hate crimes against African-Americans which were not often discussed by the white press. While the newspaper supported the African-American community, it championed for issues such as the hiring of Black police officers, the improvement of education in public schools, and federally funded public housing. To learn more read here https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/eed16

Today we celebrate Introduce a Girl to #Engineering Day. It is an exciting way to encourage girls to consider a future in engineering. As a typically male-dominated profession, the engineering field often lacks the talent and passion of young women and the contribution they make in the scientific and technology community. Each year, the day showcases workshops, lab tours and hands-on activities which encourage girls to be open with their love of science and to have new experiences in science.

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor John Biggers. John Biggers was an internationally recognized artist and educator who brought his talents to Houston, Texas to found a Negro art department at Texas State University in 1949. Biggers focused his work, including murals, sculptures, and prints, on the depiction of African-American and West African cultures and figures in an effort to expose African-Americans and the general public to accurate and positive representations of Black culture. To learn more read here: http://americanart.si.edu/collections/search/artist/?id=414

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Sutton Elbert Griggs. Sutton Elbert Griggs was a novelist and minister born and raised in Chatfield, Texas in 1872. Driven by his desire to uplift his community through his work, Griggs wrote many of his novels, books, and pamphlets for “the aspiring classes of the Black South.” While Griggs pushed for Black nationalism through his writing, he also involved himself in the Niagara Movement and the NAACP to fight for the social and political advancement of African-Americans in the United States. To learn more read here: https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fgr85

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Carter G. Woodson. Carter G. Woodson began Negro History Week (later Black History Month) in 1926. Woodson used his passion for Black history to fuel his social activism for the advancement of African-Americans.

#BlackHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Arthur Ashe Arthur Ashe was a tennis player during the 1960s-70s who became the first Black man to win at the U.S. Open and Wimbledon. After learning that he had contracted AIDS as a result of a blood transfusion, Ashe stood as an activist for awareness until his death in 1993. To learn more read here: http://www.arthurashe.org/life-story.html

Happy #WomensHistoryMonth. Join us as we celebrate the lives of women who have courageously taken to the front lines in the revolution to be seen, heard, respected and treated equally with their talents and knowledge. Included will be women from our great state of Texas that have paved the way and inspired so many generations of young girls and women.  Our first #WomensHistoryMonth spotlight: Carrie Marcus.  Carrie Marcus (1883-1953) Carrie Marcus was a buyer, saleswoman who became one of the highest paid working women in Dallas at the age of 21. With her brother, Herbert, Marcus opened a sales promotion business in Atlanta, GA which was later sold for $25,000. With profits made from the sale of their promotion business, in 1907 the Marcus siblings opened Neiman Marcus, a clothing department store founded with the intention of being “a new fashion center for Southern women.” The business has since expanded to include 42 locations nationwide and is now worth upwards of $6 billion. To learn more read here: https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fne30

#WomensHistoryMonth spotlight: Janis Joplin  Janis Joplin (1943-1970) At a young age, Janis Joplin began to develop a taste for blues which inspired her to pursue a singing career after graduating high school in Port Arthur, Texas. Joplin worked Austin’s club circuit and eventually found herself in San Francisco performing with a psychedelic rock band at the Monterrey Pop Festival in 1967. Her appearance spurred her rise to fame as a singer of blues, soul, and rock with an unforgettable, distinctive voice. After releasing three albums, Joplin’s career was cut short due to a drug overdose at the age of 27. To learn more read here: http://www.biography.com/people/janis-joplin-9357941

#WomensHistoryMonth spotlight: Today we honor Selena.  Selena (1971-1995) Selena Quintanilla-Perez was a successful Latin pop entertainer who was posthumously deemed the “Queen of Tejano Music.” Selena was one of the first crossover artists to achieve success on both the pop and Tejano charts. Throughout her relatively short music career, Selena received a double platinum award and a Grammy for Selena Live along with a quadruple platinum award for Amor Prohibido. Tragically, at the height of her career, Selena was murdered by her managing assistant and president of her fan club in 1995. To learn more read here: http://www.biography.com/people/selena-189149 <%22>

#WomensHistoryMonth spotlight: Edith Wilmans   Edith Wilmans (1882-1966) Dallas native, Edith Wilmans was the first woman elected to the Texas legislature. Prior to her election, Wilmans worked as a suffrage organizer in Dallas in 1914 and was later admitted to the State Bar Association in 1918. In 1922, Wilmans was elected to the House of Representatives where she pushed for legislation improving child care and child support. She also fought for the establishment of the Dallas County District Court of Domestic relations. Although she had success in the House, Wilmans unsuccessfully ran for governor of Texas in 1924 and 1926. To learn more read here: https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fwi48

#WomensHistoryMonth spotlight: Bette Graham  Bette Graham (1924-1980) Working as an executive secretary in Dallas, Bette Graham found that the messy solution of correcting typing errors must be fixed. To reduce disarray while making the task more efficient, Graham concocted an idea to paint over her mistakes. Graham then turned her kitchen into a laboratory and her garage into a manufacturing plant to support her typo solution business in 1956. Today marks the 52nd anniversary of one of the key events in the Civil Rights movement, “Bloody Sunday.” On Sunday, March 7th, 1965, some six-hundred civil rights protesters marched from Selma, AL en route to the state capitol in Montgomery, AL. Activists, led by SNCC leader John Lewis and SCLC member Hosea Williams, marched in protest of the controversial state trooper-involved shooting of Jimmie Lee Jackson, a 26 year old deacon who was injured while attempting to protect his mother from the trooper’s nightstick. Crossing the Edmund Pettus Bridge, protesters were met with a blockade of state troopers and local law enforcement. Refusing to return to Selma, protesters were subjected to tear gas and injuries sustained from billy club attacks. Although the crowd was driven back to Selma, the events which occurred on “Bloody Sunday” inspired momentum for the passage of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Today, we celebrate the significance of the hard work of protesters in fighting for the civil rights of all Americans. #BloodySunday

Congresswoman Johnson began A World of Women for World Peace in 2001 to bring a greater visibility to women who are victims of war and aggression and the women who promote peacekeeping and peace-building activities in their communities. As policymakers, we have the unique opportunity to work alongside both women and men leaders to help them access the necessary resources to effectively implement peace strategies in their communities.   This year’s conference will address the region’s conflict and ways to promote peace. The Israel-Palestine region presents arguably the world’s most controversial and complex conflict. Beginning in the mid-20th century, the struggle between Israelis and Palestinians generates a wide array of views. The A World of Women for World Peace initiative is based upon the Women, Peace, and Security Agenda developed by the United Nations (UN) Secretary-General at the Hague Convention as a result of the UN Security Council’s Resolution 1325 in 2000.  Keynote Speakers:  Hamutal Gouri, Israeli Peace Activist, Women Wage Peace  Yousef Bashir, Palestinian Peacemaker   Peace and Justice Comment Panel: Imam Omar Suleiman Rabbi Nancy Kasten  Honorable Vonciel Jones Hill  To RSVP: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/a-world-of-women-for-world-peace-conference-hosted-by-congresswoman-eddie-bernicejohnson-tickets-33743884868
